discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Using a SHA-2 signature of a drive image provides non-repudiation during a forensics investigation. Non-repudiation is the ability to prove that a specific action or transaction was performed by a particular party and cannot be denied or repudiated later. In a forensics investigation, it is crucial to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the evidence collected, ensuring that it cannot be tampered with or altered.

When a SHA-2 (Secure Hash Algorithm 2) signature is generated for a drive image, it produces a unique and fixed-size alphanumeric hash value that represents the content of the entire drive image. Even a small change in the image's content will result in a completely different hash value. By comparing the original SHA-2 signature with the one generated during the investigation, investigators can verify that the drive image has not been modified or tampered with since it was initially collected. This process helps establish non-repudiation, as any attempt to alter the image would result in a different SHA-2 signature.

In cybersecurity, reference architecture is a document or set of
documents that provides a set of standards. As an example, a software
reference architecture documents high-level design decisions. It may stress
the need to create reusable modules and follow a specific standard related to
interfaces. Some software reference architecture documents list procedures,
functions, and methods that a software project should use.
You won’t find a single reference architecture that meets the needs of
all projects. Instead, the key is that complex projects often use one to
standardize everyone’s efforts on a project.
